Award.AwardTitle: Lamont-Doherty Core Repository: Curation, Service, Professional Development and Outreach
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal seeks to continue funding for the deep-sea core and sample repository at Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (LDEO). The repository has distributed over 15,000 samples over the past three years. Additional funds are sought for the replacement of corroding sample trays and for some inexpensive analyses to aid sample selection. LDEO provides significant support to the facility, especially personnel and IT. The facility also offers opportunities for student training and research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
THE LAMONT-DOHERTY CORE REPOSITORY

(http://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/core-repository)

The Lamont-Doherty Core Repository (LDCR) contains one of the world’s most unique and important collections of scientific samples from the deep sea. The collection contains 20,000 sediment and coral cores from every major ocean and sea. In addition to physical samples, a database of the Lamont core collection has been maintained for nearly 50 years and contains information on the geographic location of each collection site, core length, mineralogy and paleontology, lithology, and structure, and more recently, the full text of megascopic descriptions.

Over the nearly seven decades of its existence, this unique and unparalleled facility has evolved from the scientific collection of a small number of extraordinary Lamont scientists to the present-day repository which serves the national and international Earth Science community.  Maurice Ewing’s (our founder) foresight in collecting “A core-a-day” created a scientific legacy that now constitutes one of Earth Science’s foremost oceanographic and geologic resources. It is because of this function, service to the community, that the LDCR receives significant operational funding from the National Science Foundation.

The Lamont-Doherty Core Repository serves the national and international ocean research and teaching communities and receives funding from both the National Science Foundation and Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory. Our primary function is to provide for long-term storage and curation of geological materials. In addition, samples from cores and dredges, descriptions of cores and dredges, digital images and other cruise information from the collection at L-DEO are provided to scientific investigators upon receipt of requests. Materials for educational purposes and museum displays may also be made available in limited quantities where requests are adequately justified. Finally, we also provide analytical services that we charge at cost. 

Over the term of this funding period, material was collected from the East Coast of the United States as part of the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management's Atlantic Sand Assessment Project who's goal is to identify new sources of sand to potentially be used to rebuild beaches and dunes after devastating storms like Hurricane Sandy. This is the second cruise of the program: the material collected in 2015 (and archived at the LDCR) was part of a reconnaissance operation that cored material off the coasts of all states from Florida to Maine. This year's cruise focused on the New York and New Jersey coastlines and added 176 cores to the previous 160 cores.

In addition to physical samples, the Lamont-Doherty Core Repository's new Itrax XRF Core Scanner (installed March 2016) has been used by Principal Investigators and graduate students (with several undergraduate helpers), from both inside and outside Columbia University, to acquire over half a million data points. These projects ranged from looking at the Hudson River sediments for both environmental and time markers, examination of deep sea cores from the Pacific, Atlantic, and Indian Oceans to test hypotheses about long-term climate evolution, and several sets of rock cores to identify volcanic ash layers and related history of volcanism.  The instrument has also been used to examine historical cores in our collection for a number of projects, and was recently the focus of a one-day short course at Lamont that was attended by approximately 50 scientists and students interested in learning more about XRF scanning technology and applications.

The lab is well suited for class seminars on sediment from acquisition to processing. There is a vast collection of prepared slides as well and workers skilled in sedimentology for instruction and assistance. A widening circle of social sciences have begun to appreciate the value of Earth Science sampling, and visit to better understand how natural processes such as glaciers, islands and mud record and preserve data from ancient climates and landscapes. Over the term of our last funding cycle, we welcomed over 1,300 visitors to the repository. These range from high school to college students, Boy Scout troops, and the UN Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf (to name a few). The Repository trained 27 graduate and undergraduate students in procedures for sampling and operating various equipment. Scientists involved with the LDCR were interviewed for many media programs from local college stations (CUNY and Columbia U.) to the BBC, the History Channel, Al Jazeera, and the Voice of America radio program.

Students, high school and undergraduate, are hired as part-timers to carry out the varied and unending chores that arise in a large facility. The students are exposed to a broad range of investigators, research, and deep-sea material. This is often the first real science to which a student has been exposed. 

The Repository Web Site is continually updated with news, projects and research involving samples from our collections and we have Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/corerepository) and Twitter accounts (@corerepository) that highlight significant research and activities, both current and historical, related to our collection.
